awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Multiscale Study of Active Cellular Matter: Simulation, Modeling, and Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Active cellular matter is the basis of novel synthetic active fluids made of mixtures of suspended cytoskeletal filaments and molecular motors. By consuming chemical fuel, the molecular motors (e.g., kinesins) can bind to and create actively moving crosslinks between the biofilaments (e.g., microtubules) to drive their relative motion, which leads to large-scale collective motions in the filament/motor mixture through hydrodynamic coupling. Synthetic active suspensions made of small numbers of components reveal how higher-order aspects of assembly and organization are built in living cells. These systems also present new challenges to our understanding, design, and analysis of materials, and have the potential to provide valuable new technologies such as autonomously moving and self-healing materials.

In this work, the investigators study active cellular matter composed of microtubules and molecular motors through multiscale methods, and tightly coupled modeling, analysis, and simulation. The project aims to understand the fundamental interactions underlying stress generation within bundles of rigid/flexible biofilaments that undergo dynamic instability, as well as the nonlinear dynamics and hierarchical pattern formation in large-scale collective motions. The project will also predict key material properties including its coherent structures, local heterogeneity, time- and length-scales, and material rheology. To resolve the physics at different length- and time-scales, several methods will be developed and integrated: (1) microtubule-motor interactions will be simulated using a kinetic Monte Carlo method; (2) the hydrodynamic interactions between objects of various shapes will be modeled using a nonlocal slender body/boundary integral method, together with fast summation methods; (3) a pseudo-spectral method will be implemented to simulate the collective motion through a continuous active liquid-crystal type model.

por.por_cntn:
Active matter defines the novel class of nonequilibrium materials made up of self-driven constituents. They present scientific challenges to our understanding of material properties and have the potential to provide new technologies such as autonomously moving and self-healing materials. One important class originates from cellular matter where microtubules and motor proteins self-organized into biologically important assemblies. Outside of cells, microtubule-motor mixtures can form novel active liquid-crystalline materials driven out of equilibrium by ATP-consuming motor proteins.

The NSF supported research project was dedicated to understanding how interacting microtubules within bundles generate stresses that lead to nonlinear dynamics and hierarchical pattern formation in large-scale collective motions. The multiscale nature of the complex dynamics raises considerable challenges in mathematical models and numerical simulations. While particle-based simulations can represent microscopic interactions in detail, the computational cost typically limits cross-scale studies. Continuum models are more tractable for describing dynamics at large scales, but can be difficult to connect to the microscopic dynamics quantitatively. To overcome these difficulties, we constructed a bottom-up hybrid computational framework where the Brownian dynamics/Monte-Carlo simulator resolved the stochastic process of motor complex binding onto/unbinding from motile microtubules, and the kinetic models and macroscale liquid crystal models resolve the spontaneous active flows.

Furthermore, using the coarse-grained liquid crystal model, we demonstrated geometric confinements, when properly designed,  can guide and control the spontaneous flows and coherent structures. We revealed a series of phase transitions in a curved annulus geometry with rigid walls, including unidirectional circulations, traveling waves, and chaotic flows in dilute suspensions. We also captured intriguing quasi-steady coherent structures featured by traveling wave flows that carry oscillating defects in concentrated regimes. Moreover, we designed and investigated a single self-driven droplet which encapsulated a dense suspension comprising non-motile but mobile active particles that generate extensile stresses. We showed that such droplets can be driven into motion and can have tunable mobilities due to their internal collective motion, characterized by induced active flows and motile disclination defects. We showed that the interplay among the internal directional flows, liquid crystalline structures, droplet size, and surface tension resulted in different locomotion and rotation types.

Last, we combined coarse-grained models with discrete particle simulation to characterize the material properties of dense rod suspensions. A geometric-constrained optimization algorithm was utilized to resolve rod-rod penetration, eliminating irregular near-contact dynamics previously seen when using phenomenological steric potentials. Following the bottom-up hybrid method, we characterized the long-time Brownian rotational diffusivity for dense rod suspensions that undergo phase transitions. We show that the measured non-monotonic diffusivity over a wide range of aspect ratios can be explained by an analytical tube model.

In general, we find this hybrid multiscale computation framework has the potential to recover rich nonequilibrium physics in active matter systems. We anticipate the multiscale method, together with the numerical tools developed, will provide a new angle in material characterization in a wide variety of soft condensed matter. This NSF project supported one Ph.D. student. There have been five publications in the journals in the areas of computational physics and mathematics.
